title: Orca 0.43 X-axis HGR15 and HGH15CA linear carriage and raceway upgrade

description.text: This is an upgrade to the Orca 0.43 x-axis. I bought a raceway 360mm long, anything up to 373/374mm long should fit fine. If in the UK, http://www.marchantdice.com are great, and extremely local to me. They'll cut it to the length you specify, just make sure to email them for a quote/paypal payment, as their website doesn't have selectable prices for lengths. As the raceway is completely rigid and straight, it stops any bowing of the axis due to tension between the original two rails, which was causing a rise in the nozzle in the middle of the bed, making it difficult to level the bed. It also frees up the front of the carriage for a fan, whilst still using the original top aluminium plate. The only issue with this now, is that the original mounting bolts for the extruder can no longer be used as the carriage is in the way. I've used M4 threaded rod and penny washers to rectify this.

Remove all the extruder, belt holder, and one rear bearing holder from the carriage. Use the drilling jig to drill four new holes for the HGH15CA carriage, then countersink them.  
Use M4x8mm CSK SKT bolts to attach the carriage to the x-axis plate, and then fit the carriage to the rail.  
Fit nylock nut and normal nut to the mounting bracket, then push the mounting brackets onto the rail, making sure to get the holes in the bracket on the right side of the printer, as these are mirrored. Fix to the frame using M4x20mm bolts, and clamp the raceway using M4x25mm bolts.  
Use the new belt-clamp (the old one doesn't fit anymore), and push two M3 nuts into the recesses. Push the clamp down onto the belt, and tighten using M3x10mm bolts to clamp. Fit to x-axis plate using M4x16mm bolts.  
Assemble extruder as normal, but using M4 threaded bar, penny washers and nylocks instead of the original bolts. The penny washers should pull up on the underside of the HGH15CA carriage.  
You can also use M4 threaded rod to fix the x-axis opto if you like. Use nuts to tighten to the frame, then nuts to lock the opto holder in place.

A set of marble run pieces.
My 4 year old son has grown fond of marble runs recently, so we purchased a "deluxe marble run" set.  I figured I could make this a "mega deluxe marble run" set by adding custom pieces.

Print out as many as you want, connect, add standard (~16mm) marbles and have fun!
All parts are 60mm high, and have print length of 120mm (so that it will fit on my up plus).
Currently a straight piece, a curve (left) and a riser.
I will add more pieces in the future.
If people want, I can also upload the Alibre files (.ad_prt).

This fixture makes it easy to cut small gauge brass or aluminum tubing with a regular hobby knife

I printed this tool in PLA with 40% fill. The set screw hole is tapped directly into the plastic to accept a 10-32 screw, since that's what I had handy. If you don't have a tapping set, redesign to use a captured nut instead. Set the correct length; then insert your tube and roll under the knife blade. The guide will keep the blade at a right angle to the tube. As you roll back and forth, a gradually deepening groove will be cut, until the tube snaps off clean. The tool accommodates tubing 1/4" diameter or smaller. I used it to build my planetary gear drive. This video shows the tool in use. If you're impatient, scroll to 3:20 http://youtu.be/P-Obt-9tZVo

comments.text: Wow. I wish I had this tube cutter a few years back. I use aluminum tubes which are identical to the brass ones you're using, and I used exactly the same cutting technique, but it was damned hard to get the initial groove to line up, and harder when the tube segments were so short.
comments.author: ThingHuxter

title: LED light holder for Printrbot+ and LC

description.text: This clip will clamp an inexpensive USB LED light source to the base of a Printrbot+ (and likely LC as well).

Purchase USB-powered LED lights. The model I bought is listed at Amazon as "Energy Saving USB LED Laptop Notebook Light" and sells for $2 with free shipping. I bought 4. Optional: purchase molex to dual-usb cable. I bought two from coolerguys.com, they're listed as "4 pin Molex to Dual USB 5V Power Connecter". With this cable, the USB LED lights can draw power from the Printrbot power supply. Printing:
Bring the file 'light holder5.stl' into your favorite slicing app, output gcode, print. I went with .1mm layers and 100% infill. Though I carefully measured the LED shaft and the wall of the Printrbot+ base when designing the clip in sketchup and all should be well, I found that I had to scale the clip in slic3r to 102% in order for everything to fit together, and it's a tight fit. Scaling to 102.5% might make installation easier, but the clips are held in place by friction so at some point scaling them up will become counterproductive. Assembly:
Snap the round end of the clip over the thin part of the LED light cable and slide the thicker, inflexible portion of the base of the LED light into the clip. Then attach the other side of the clip onto the Printrbot+ base. See attached images for details.

comments.text: This looks real nice! I was thinking about putting some light (and perhaps a webcam) on my Printrbot, then stumbled upon your project here while looking through comments/likes on my last projects.

The Rostock rods were taking 45 minutes apiece on my printer, and I was really wishing I could print more than one at once. Problem is, it just barely fits on the build platform, so you can't just make a plate like normal.
Instead, I pulled this into solidworks and basically added a raft-like feature on top so I could stack them.
They don't come out as pretty this way (though messing with slicing settings could help), but they do look like they'll work just fine.
I haven't printed them the full 6 up, but I printed up to 3 and its pretty solid, so I think 6 up would work just fine. I added a six up version and a 3 up version. 3 up might be best so you can test the slicing parameters and make sure it works before spending more time.

Slice, with some settings to deal with the bridging. Concentric fill might be a good idea.
After printing, carefully separate with a sturdy sharp knife. Starting from one end seems to work well.

title: Arduino RAMPS 1.4 Prusa Support with fan

description.text:
This is a support for RAMPS 1.4 and arduino on a Mendel Prusa.
It locates the whole electronics on the upper section of the printer.
It also features the possibility to add a 90mm fan to cool down the stepper drivers as well as a central filament guide.
The original model was printed in ABS with a 0.20mm layer height. Takes about 3h30 to print.
NOTE: The support for the fan has to be treated gently. I will reinforce the columns in a future revision.

• Rotate model to convenience
  • Print
  • Install:
    Part attaches to the upper threaded rods of the Prusa, no additional hardware required.

A simple balloon powered jet car designed with Solidworks and builded with a Replicator (1.75 filament, 0.4 nozzle)

built four weels, four axes (A.STL), four hat ( which should be put at the axes end) and one car and your done !   
use low infill ( I use 0.17) for the car to improve thrust-to-weight ratio :)  
put a little balloon on the top tube, blow in the rear opening to inflate it and ...fire !

description.text:
Leash plug GoPro mount for bodyboard.  
Please note: version 2 of mount part added - more robust and easier to print.  
You will also need standard partially threaded size 10 hex cap bolt (approx 64 mm - 2.5 inch length) to assemble the mount.  
You can glue the top peg together with mount to increase construct stability.  
I have printed this with Replicator 2X using ABS and HIPS supports at 0.2 mm resolution using 3 shells and 80% fill.  
I think it can print nicely without supports. Let me know how it goes.

A wheel designed to slot into the slots on the bottom of IKEA's Komplement large plastic store box.

I designed this as an experiment.
Print with the axle vertical so all bearing surfaces are running 'along' the filament (not across steps).
The .Scad file has lots of parametrics the all important taper angle can be changed and things will mostly follow.
THe angles are all designed to hopefully self support...I printed the photo item in ABS, the angles are 40 degrees from flat, which is ok except for where the holes or small features are. I intend to eliminate the wheel holes and just sparse fill. If that isnt solid enough in the axles where the most load is, I will re-instate the central void and solid fill the rest.
( I printed a ultimaker fan duct which has large 30 degree from horizontal faces...which worked beautifully in PLA ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:17768 ) )

title: RepRapPro Ormerod Extruder Gears - Double Helix / Herringbone

description.text: Replacement extruder gear for RepRapPro Ormerod. Modified from iamburny's design, meant to work with the small gear from that. Should use a bit less material and print cleaner and quicker, while being at least as strong as the original design.

Should be easy enough to get to print. Reasonable slicer settings would be 3 perimeter layers, 3 top/bottom solid layers, and 0.2 infill (line, rectilinear or hex should all do nicely). Print the small gear from iamburny to go with this,

title: HD TSM Bracket
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: This is a bracket for the Harley Davidson VRSCx Turn Signal Module (TSM). It fits my VROD '02 model TSM and from what I can tell in other pictures it should suit others. I haven't seen the alarm/keyfob Turn Signal Security Module (TSSM) but I'm guessing that is probably rather different and wouldn't fit this bracket. The extension to the bracket enabled me to mount the device in the air box area, correctly oriented (since when at or close to horizontal the TSM cuts power to the bike, thinking that you've just crashed). Other mounting positions would probably require redesign of the bracket. PS: Yes, this is probably too exotic and not of use to anyone else, but I'm keeping it here for the sake of completeness. The tapered curves were annoying at the beginning but I'm glad I got it eventually.

• Buy a HD VROD
  • Rewire your bike in order to relocate your TSM to the air box area
  • Print this on a 3D printer and wedge the TSM into it, plug in the wires and then wedge the whole kaboodle in between the air filter and the wall of the air box.
  • Drill holes through the bracket and side of the air box if you feel the need for a fixed mounting (mine is tight enough that it works fine without bolts).

comments.text: Do you have a picture of how you mounted in your airbox? I have an 06 night rod
comments.author: shaggy4586

comments.text: Bike sold a while back sorry. Might be able to dig up a photo in situ though. From memory  the back right of the model (as seen on this Thingiverse page) needs to be downward (towards the road).

title: UV5R Speaker Mic Cable Support Bracket

description.text:
The BAOFENG (and clones) budget radio benefits from some matching budget speaker-mics available from online auction sites. Unfortunately although the  jacks fit well, it only needs a small lateral force on the jack to create a poor connection. This results in poor, intermittent or no operation of the device.  
After messing about with several fixes including using rubber bands and glue to support the jack in the correct place I finally designed a proper bracket to support the speaker-mic cable. It holds the cable in such a way as to prevent lateral forces from disconnecting it thus maintaining a good connection.

I used FREECAD to generate the 3D design file.
I used an ULTIMAKER to build the part. Settings are 220C, 15%infill, 75mm/second speed. The design is in metric mm.
You should be able to print it straight off at 1:1 scale. Print out the part.
Unscrew the two screws for the belt clip
You will need two M2.5 x 10mm set screws as the originals won't be long enough.
Fit the speaker mic to the printed part as per the photographs
Plug it into the radio body.
Carefully re-assemble the belt-clip, bracket and set screws. You may find the holes for the set screw are a bit tight, this is deliberate so it all holds together. However you can easily widen the holes a bit using the point of a soldering iron.

comments.text: This is great. Any chance you'd be willing to make some modifications?
comments.author: enkoopa

comments.text: The source files are included. You can open and edit them using FREECAD. It works on Linux and Windows. And best of all it is free so go ahead and make any improvements you like. Chris.
comments.author: enkoopa

comments.text: Thanks - I got Designspark and I think I managed to get your design copied and improved slightly. I'll do some test prints soon at the library and let you know how it worked out :) I added a wing to protect the transmit buttons from being pushed, as well as a top hood to protect the volume knob from being rotated.
comments.author: engineer_chris

This is a derivative work of Coin-op Bottle Opener by Hoeken.
Makerbot branded bottle opener for giveaways.
UPDATE: I found a problem with the makerbot_bottle_opener2.stl causing the letters to be at different heights.  Now its fixed and uploaded 5/18/10
Makerbot bottle opener.stl is an embossed logo, opener 2.stl is a bigger embossed logo, and cut.stl is a debossed logo.
Print and insert US Dime or similar sized coin/metal.

comments.text: Starno, what program and how did you get the embossing to go evenly around a curve?
comments.author: Dogbert

comments.text: I used SolidWorks to add the logo, and I remember the curve gave me a lot of trouble.  It may be easier to do with other software.  I used a process refered to as "surfacing", which means you define the outer contours or boundaries of what you want to create whereas the more traditional process involves extruding and cutting away planar geometry.
comments.author: Dogbert

comments.text: Did you have to reverse engineer the thing in Solidworks? Or is there a way to import an STL and modify it from there? I've wanted to make a few with peoples names on them. I've only found that you can import an STL into Solidworks but you cant do anything to it.
comments.author: Starno

comments.text: I dont know how to modify STLs in SolidWorks. I originally had to import the dxf hoeken designed here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1813http://www.thingiverse.com/thi... and convert that into a workable sketch.

title: Coin Sorting Trays
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Stack Them, and shake them. and your work is done.

Object size is 120mm x 120mm x 30mm
45 Degree supports suggested. Added a OpenSCad File to make your own trays. just open it up set the var and have let it fly! Stack up the trays from smallest to largest, put the solid tray on the bottom. then shake them. Trays are labeled for the hole in them not the coin they collect. For example the Dime tray will collect Pennies letting dimes through, and the quarter tray will collect 50cent coins letting all others through. inspired to build this thx to this post by IWorkInPixels
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:30571
wish him luck in finishing his mechanism.

title: Grill clip for Isuzu, Mazda, Toyota, Mitsubishi

description.text:
While pulling my mazda apart to fix something I noticed that a few clips on the grill were missing/broken so I made some new ones that work perfectly in its place. Replaces:
For Isuzu Replaces 8942180270
For Mazda Replaces B092-50-715
For Toyota Replaces 90467-13011
For Mitsubishi Replaces MB153825 May also suit :

remixed_from.title: AC PrintrBot LC v2 40mm Fan Mount

description.text:
This adjustable fan mount prevents reliably extruder cloggings. I previously had big problems especially in slower passages. I use a 12 volt 40 mm fan, which is running with 5 volt on a seperate power supply. That's sufficient for cooling down the extruder above the nozzle and therefore to avoid the clogging. Additionally the fresh breeze is cooling the stepper motor for the filament. It is the first part that I uploaded yet. It could have been done better, but it works. (Update)
Version 2 is self-supporting. Just use a zip tie to hold it in place. (Update)
The third and probably last version got a tube to direct the air flow more precisely. (Update - Final)
Added a channel for the zip tie and a gap for the bolt at the extruder arm.

3D Printing has been all over the news lately as a way to rapidly design custom prosthetics for amputees. Some examples: http://www.reuters.com/video/2012/02/27/3d-printed-prosthetics-offer-amputees-ne?videoId=230878689 http://news.yahoo.com/wounded-eagle-gets-3d-printed-beak-212747462.html We thought it was about time this same level of medical care was offered to stuffed animals. -- Subject is a 15-year old stuffed pig, whose right arm was lost to a vicious animal in a horrifying accident. Doctors carefully measured the pig's left arm to create a duplicate that would be virtually identical to the original limb in fit and function. Because the hospital has a Prusa Reprap 3D Printer on hand, the doctors were able to design and 3D print a prosthetic in no time at all, and now the pig is once again able to perform all the activites it enjoyed before the vicious attack claimed its original arm. -- Guide to Photos: 1 & 2: The patient as initially admitted to the clinic. Note the missing arm has been inexpertly bandaged by a previous doctor. 3: This photograph of the 3D printer creating the prosthetic illustrates how we have filled the interior of the prosthetic with 'plastic stuffing' in order to simulate the pig's original limb. 4+: It's a stunning replica of his original limb; one can hardly notice it is artificial. It retains all the function of the original limb. Final Photo: Complete success means our patient is able to re-integrate into his previous lifestyle. He can now pass for a normal stuffed pig, without being ostracized for being different. -- Link to the flickr: http://www.flickr.com/photos/[email protected]/sets/72157631557873975/with/7996231007/

This is a realistic model of the famous Brooklyn Bridge. I have so many incredible memories: love, inspiration, and admiration for this bridge. There was no 3D-printable models anywhere, and nothing like this on thingverse, so I thought I had to attempt an epic model. This is for everyone that wants a little reminder of a landmark that may have inspired them.   
This was designed to fit in a Replicator 2 build platform.  
Be cautious, it's fully assembled dimensions are: 36"L x 6.5"H x 2.85"W. This takes some serious build time, and I have yet to make it.

You will need to print the following quantities of each part uploaded:
2x 1_Pier.STL
4x 2_RoadWay_Standard.STL
2x 3_RoadWay_PinBase1.STL
2x 4_RoadWay_PinBase2.STL
4x 5_Left Center Stays.STL
4x 6_Right Center Stays.STL
4x 7_Right Stays.STL
4x 8_Left Stays.STL
2x 9_Pier Cap.STL
2x 10_The FLag.STL Start by assembling 2 identical roadways, It is made of 2x RoadWay_Standard's and 1x of the PinBase1 and 2. The pins that connect the roadways face to the left, so make sure to place them in the Pier's that way. It may help to glue all of these pieces together before continuing. The next step is attaching the stays. Left Center refers to the 4 stays that get attached on the left Pier (as denoted by the direction the pins faced while making the roadways) in the center section between the 2 piers. Right Center refers to the right section between the 2 piers. Right stays go on the right side of the right pier, and same with the left stays. I have never built this, but the way it was designed is to have a press (friction) fit on top of the pier's and individually push in the stay loops on to the pins on the roadway. Glue may be required. Once all the stays are on, The Pier Caps can be placed on top to cover the top stay anchor points. Throw the flags on top (would love to see some painted American Flag up there) and you'll be good to display!

A derivative of agwn's sleeve, but with an extra box on the side that's a press fit for a small slider switch.

There is a small quadrant shaped hole through which you poke the positive lead from a battery clip. Cut the red wire and solder it across the switch and pass the black wire through the round hole.  Twist the wires together.
The switch is a common or garden variety I had lying around, but it's a nice snug fit and needs no glue.

title: Laser cut pi symbol cut from 788 digits of the never ending number.

remixed_from.author: TexasLaser
remixed_from.title: Laser cut gear O'clock with a redesigned hour wheel.

title: Laser Cut Gear O'clock.  New face and hour wheel design.

description.text:
Laser Cut O'clock. New face and hour wheel design.
My latest version of the O'Clock. Scenery and an arc over the hour showing the minute on the new face. After redesigning the hour wheel last week, it made me think some and I came up with this new clock works holder/face design. There are now 3 minutes indicators.
Dial, which is read at the bottom.
Tab, which is read like a traditional clock. Good for far away viewing.
Now the position of the hour tab shows minutes also. I added some scenery to enhance it even more. Make your own background.

comments.text:
I've made one but the hour dial does not move an hour in a hour's time.
The mechanism works fine with the normal hands.
I've made it out of 3mm MDF, can it be too heavy?
Thanks
Attie du Raan
comments.author: RADURAAN

This object is an improved motor clamp plate for the Replicator Extruder. This upgraded part has a stop to prevent the filement guide tube collets from sliding down and out of position.

I uses a scale factor of 1.008 to compensate for thermal shrinkage.
I built this part out of ABS plastic and used a 20% infill.
Once built, I popped the tubing collets out of the original OEM part and pressed them into my new part. Make sure you put the solid ring end UP (see finished picture).

The Lyman Filament Extruder is a machine that extrudes filament from pellets for use in a 3D Printer. It can extrude 1.75mm and 3mm filament with easy nozzle exchange. The material cost is about $250.

This filament extruder has been entered in the DESKTOP FACTORY COMPETITION. The attached PDF file is a Manual which includes Fabrication and Operational instructions, including BOM, tools, photo's and drawings. See thing #30705 for the Lyman Filament Spool Winder. Click on hlyman for my things. View video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JebhbxgjBgA

comments.text: I see you have a lot of experience with building DIY filament extruders, I find them very interesting. However I know diameter consistency is very hard to achieve with these materials and therefore you print quality will go down. I have been thinking... wouldn't it be possible to measure the diameter of the filament at a fixed point and adjust the flow of the printer in real time while printing. It sure would be a challenge but more diy filament could be used. For example, use two wheels, one fixed wheel, one attached on a sliding potentiometer with a spring pushing it against the fixed wheel, an arduino could measure the power and adjust the speed of the filament feeder. Just came up with the idea, thought it might be useful for the development of these diy extruders. Keep up the good work, love what you are doing!
comments.author: AndresVH

comments.text: Folks,  I am not supporting any other Lyman Extruder now except V6 (Lyman Filament Extruder V6).  I have three working one for white, one for black and the third for other colors. My last 1 kg spool tested at +/- .03mm.  It is vertically mounted and the spool wind system is separate.

comments.text:
May I have a few questions? From your experience, what is the general reason for air bubble? When you set the temperature to 212 Celsius degree, did the filament run out of the nozzle by its own? And the last one, when I first extruded the filament, the motor run smoothly and I had about 1m good condition filament, but then the motor get stucked, the vicous filament run out with air bubble, what do you think might be the reason?
Thank you.
comments.author: scorbi

comments.text:
• Maybe your pellets are different than mine were.
  • Motor stopping could be, a) to fast, b) not hot enough.
  • Have no idea about the bubbles, as I haven't had that problem.
comments.author: scorbi

comments.text:
Congratulations for your win. A very well designed machine. The budget constraints must have made this challenging. I wish that I had a workshop handy to try and make one myself.
Was wondering how frequently the diameter of filament would vary over eg say one meter while you are extruding? Also approximately how fast does the wiper motor rotate?
If it is very stable then it would be not worth this extra effort. Exchanging the voltage regulator for a motor speed controller kit - eg a pulse width modulated one. Shine a light at a point near the extrusion nozzle. Then use a photoresistor on the other side as an input to fine tune the speed controller to push slightly more material if it thins etc. This tweak might be far too simplistic but is less complex than a computer control chip but these DIY kits seem to be around the $20 mark.
comments.author: Tony3D

comments.text:
Tony3D, thanks for the congrats.
Your idea sounds interesting, but the filament as it comes out of the nozzle is soft and it stretches so the control has to be after it exits. I am working now on the 3rd version with a gear motor plus a water bath and a re-rounding die to control the diameter.
comments.author: Tony3D

comments.text: I am excited to let all know that I did win the DFC contest. See link below.

comments.text: Some plastic extruders are cooled by water.Â  You can find a drinking straw extruder example on YouTube.Â  However, you don't want to cool plastic for a 3d printer in water.Â  The plastic absorbs water overtime and causes problems with extruding.Â  So, the goal through the whole life of the filament is to AVOID water and moisture.

comments.text: Â The width consistency is good if it is not disturb as it exits the nozzle. That is why the setup lets the filament fall to the floor. I hope the Lyman Filament Spool Winder will solve this.Â  Three variables also affect the width (diameter): Nozzle hole, Temperature and Speed of the motor.Â  All can be adjusted.Â  The nozzle is drilled with a 0.063" #52 drill bit.Â  My first run was extruding at 1.60mm, so I reamed the hole with the same bit again and then I got 1.70mm+ diameter.

Adsorption tube is an analytical technique for gases sampling. It is either a glass or stainless steel tube, which is filled with either an inorganic or organic solid (sorbent) with high surface area. Choosing appropriately the sorbent, you can sample some chemical compounds by adsorption. You can order tubes filled with a specific sorbent or you can order empty tubes and fill them by yourself. The holder and funnel should help one to fill the tube. Credits Carlos A. Neves - IAG-USP (ideia and finishing), Adalgiza Fornaro - IAG-USP (supervisor), and Claudimir L. do Lago - IQ-USP (design and execution). Acknowledgment The authors thank the financial support by Fapesp (2012/06642-1 and 2008/58104-8), CNPq (304239/2010-0) and CAPES (PNPD and Proex).

The funnel and the holder were develop using the Autodesk Inventor Professional 2014, Cura 14.03, and printed using a RepRap Mendel with 1.75mm ABS filament. The objects were sanded, cleaned, and softed in an acetone chamber.

This will hold a "naked" GoPro securely to a tripod. It allows for better sound, clearer picture and connect a USB while recording.
While it does not hold it tight enough to take a hard hit it is tight enough to keep it from moving around.

It's pretty straight forward, just print and clean up. One additional step you'll need to do is drill and tap the threads for the mount.
Drill out the printed hole to 7/32" and tap 1/4"-20.
Alternatively you could put a metal 1/4"-20 insert into the base for longer life.

description.text: A Low wing loading, high performance glider, perfect for hill and park flying. Model files (blue glider) include universal fuselage and standard wing set, in threedsy.com livery. Experimental ultra long wings (yellow) are a little tricky to print, but offer the ultimate in floating capability...available only at http://threedsy.com See the resource page : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:303563 for videos, links, and more! For tips on printing glider wings, drop by my blog at threedsy.com and if you like our models, keep us designing for you instead of flipping burgers by purchasing one of our premium designs from the site! If you like my gliders, check out my other models here on thingiverse and more models and books I wrote on 3D Design and 3D Printing here at threedsy.com If you want to learn how to design amazing, highly functional designs for 3d printing, design and print useful repair parts, and generally print useful stuff faster, more reliably, and with less problems check out my books, Functional design for 3D printing and the Zombie Apocalypse Guide to 3D Printing on Amazon!

'Paris Building' is MakerBot's third #WeekendMake. Click on the Instructions tab for print instructions and read MakerBot's blog post to be ready for the next challenge.
http://www.makerbot.com/blog/2014/07/18/makerbot-replicator-mini-weekendmake-paris/
This Parisan-style palace is absolutely lovely! Created by Jason Bakutis

Printing Instructions For MakerBot Mini
=============================
If connected via WI-FI:

• On the Thing page, click on Thing Files to see available files.
    Click on the part or version you want to print to download the thing to your computer. Click on the file once downloaded. MakerBot Desktop will open and the file you selected will appear on the build plate.
  • Click the Print button to slice your model. To send the file to your MakerBot Replicator Mini and exit the Print dialog, click Start Print.
  • When the print file is sent to the MakerBot Replicator Mini, the Action Button will blink blue. Press the Action Button to confirm the print. The Action Button will then glow red, indicating it is heating the MakerBot Replicator Smart Extruder. When the Smart Extruder is fully heated, the MakerBot Replicator Mini will start to print your model.
  • When your print finishes, wait for the Smart Extruder to cool, then remove the build plate from the MakerBot Replicator Mini. Remove the print from the build plate, and peel off the raft from the bottom of the print.
  • Every object printed on your MakerBot Replicator Mini will be built on a raft. The raft acts as a base for your object and any support structures, and ensures that everything adheres well to the build plate. The raft will be easily removable once you remove your finished object from the build plate.
  • You're almost done. Go enjoy your weekend and take your newly printed friend with you. Take a few creative photos and upload them to Thingiverse as a Make by clicking I Made One above.
    If connected via USB:
  • On the Thing page, click on Thing Files to see available files.
    Click on the part or version you want to print to download the thing to your computer. Click on the file once downloaded. MakerBot Desktop will open and the file you selected will appear on the build plate.
  • Click the Print button to slice your model. To send the file to your MakerBot Replicator Mini and exit the Print dialog, click Start Print.
  • If you decide not to send the file to the MakerBot Replicator Mini, click Cancel Print.
  • When the print file is sent to the MakerBot Replicator Mini, the Action Button will glow red, indicating it is heating the MakerBot Replicator Smart Extruder. When the Smart Extruder is fully heated, the MakerBotReplicator Mini will start to print your model.
  • When your print finishes, wait for the Smart Extruder to cool, then remove the build plate from the MakerBot Replicator Mini. Remove the print from the build plate, and peel off the raft from the bottom of the print.
  • Every object printed on your MakerBot Replicator Mini will be built on a raft. The raft acts as a base for your object and any support structures, and ensures that everything adheres well to the build plate. The raft will be easily removable once you remove your finished object from the build plate.
  • You're almost done. Go enjoy your weekend and take your newly printed friend with you. Take a few creative photos and upload them to Thingiverse as a Make by clicking I Made One above.

title: Another 40mm CPU Fan Mount for Printrbot LC+

description.text: This is a simple fan mount for the print head on a Printrbot LC+.

This uses a 40mm CPU fan, I got mine from an old computer. You'll need:
(2) 4-40 X 3/4" Phillips Head Screws with nuts and (2) flat washers. (2) 6-32 X 1 1/2" Phillips Head Screws with nuts and (2) flat washers. 1/8" Drill Bit 5/32" Drill Bit Print and clean up the mount. Drill out fan holes 1/8" Drill out mounting holes 5/32" Mount the fan using the 4-40 hardware. Mount the bracket to the print head as follows - Modify the 6-32 nuts by grinding down one edge so that they will clear the hardware on the back of the print head. Remove the two bolts in the head and install the mount using the new 6-32 hardware. Route the wiring, plug it in and start printing. The fan on mine comes very close to the printing so you should double check the fit before printing so it clears.

title: Swapping the orientation of the extruder motor/heater assembly

description.text: This modification to the Replicator extruder rotates the fans to the back and the extrusion motors to the front. I did this so I could see the ends of the extruder motors so I could better gauge the rate of extrusion. This also puts the delicate fan blades in the back so they are better protected.

This is not a object build but rather a modification to the Makerbot Replicator. While I have a dual extruder, the modification should work for the single extruder version also.  Please read the attached PDF file and understand the risks involved before doing this modification.
Now that I can see the shaft, I can better judge if the filament is slipping again the pinch rollers.
In the attached picture, you can see a white ABS disk that I glued to the end of the left extruder motor shaft so I can watch the extrusion speed.

remixed_from.author: satoer
remixed_from.title: Bowden tube feeder with filament release mechanism

title: Bowden tube feeder with filament release mechanism - 3mm version

description.text:
UPDATE 1 :
I made a little approximation modifying the top plate, and made the space for the 8mm Bearing too narrow for it to really push the filament against the hobbed bolt without touching the surrounding walls. I just corrected this so if you printed the previous version, you might need to use a dremel or a knife to remove some matter. I absolutely loved the design by satoer, and I definitely wanted this bowden mechanism on the printer I'm building! Unfortunately, it is only available for 1.75mm filament, so I had to redesign the meshs. But here it is, it is fully functionnal, and it adjusts just as it should! I made several other modifications :
  • adapted to my setup, I wanted to use a M8 ball bearing (didn't want to buy a new smaller one) so the whole box is a bit larger
  • I use a hobbed bolt, not a crancked gear, so I had to modify the hole in "top" for it to fit
  • I use a Nema14 with a gearbox, so the screw spacing is not the same
  • and finally, I of course modified the holes for the 3mm filament to fit ^^
    • Hope it gets usefull for someone around here.
    Let me know if you make it! :)

The assembly is exactly the same as described in the video made by satoer on the original object.
The modifications are made so that all keep functionning in the same way. The two only difference are:
  • It is not a screw anymore that holds the bearing, but a 8mm pipe or rod (I cut a spare length of 8mm rod from my MendelMax)
  • I made a hole in "top" for the larger bearing to fit. There are 2 supports you need to cut for the bearing to get in, and that's it!

author: Retsac

description.text:
Here is "InMoov", the robot you can print and animate. You have a 3D printer, some building skills, This project is for you!!
Don't be scared or intimidated, I started this a few months ago and didn't even know what was Arduino or a servo motor!
Start with printing the hand like I did, and go on the rest if you feel.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:17773
Well it's been a fun time creating this bicep, I have gone through quite many prints for to finally release it.
Blog with more info and instructions:
inmoov.blogspot.com
http://inmoov.blogspot.fr/p/assembly-help.html
This video isn't actual, I have modified many parts since then:
youtube.com/watch?v=XAcGlytxPVI
youtube.com/watch?v=BAs2F4sFVdA
The latest video:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=kqG7vASU1YE

THIS IS A WORK IN PROGRESS FILES MIGHT STILL CHANGE.
All parts are designed to fit on a 12x12cm print bed, just like the hand.
I have printed all parts in ABS.
With 0.5mm thickness for most parts.
Also most parts have an infill of 30%.
Except "pistonanticlock", "rotwormV4" was printed at 0.4mm with a 100% infill.
"rotwormV4" is the only part printed with support.
Most parts are the same for the left and right arm.
The parts named "leftXXXX" are for the left arm, easy to figure out...
Print one of each part.
Print two of "lowarmsideV1", "higharmsideV1"
You also need 2 Hitec HS-805BB servo.
A little bit of cables.
Update 21/09/12 A step by step Instructions uploaded on the blog
http://inmoov.blogspot.fr/p/assembly-help.html
Update 24/09/12 Something went wrong during uploading "pistonbaseV1", you should use "pistonbaseantiV1". Sorry for this mistake. Thanks to 1Robotmaker for the comment.
Update 07/10/12 Uploaded the covers for the bicep + a simple movement sketch for your Arduino seen in the Part8 video.
Update 31/10/12 RotwormV4 is now used for the left and right bicep. If you are building a right arm, you need to inverse the green and red wires on the potentiometer. See blog for more info.
Update 03/01/13 I have uploaded the shoulder parts.
see: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:40040
Update 02/03/13 Modified "RotGearV2" to "RotGearV3" teeth are now a bit smaller, avoiding the risk of touching the innercasing. Also modified "RotWormV4" to "RotWormV5", I rounded up the entrance of the worm, for better printing finish. Thanks to Brian for the suggestions.
Update 07/07/14 Modified "RotGearV3" to "RotGearV4" teeth are now angled with openings within the gear to allow cables to run through. Also the external surface of cylinder is smooth finish.
Update 21/10/14 PistonAnticlock, PistonBaseAnti and HighArmSide to V2 version. Bigger section diameter for better resistance to torsion.
Still working on instructions text...

I used my CNC machine to mill an aluminum plate to fit using the stock Ultimaker bed bolts and springs.
This is the file I used to create the G-Code for milling. And some brief instructions how to get it working.
I selected 0.25" mill finished stock from 80/20 surplus on ebay. I got enough material to make 2 beds so I can swap them in and out.

Parts needed:

  • Order a PCB (or mill your own). I chose to order from Ultamachine as they had the resistor and LEDs pre-soldered on the board. $50 with components: http://bit.ly/OUy4qk

  • Order a thermistor. Ultamachine sells one that is recognized by the Marlin firmware for $2.75: http://bit.ly/SvoHgA

  • Order a power supply. I choose to replace the power supply included with the Ultimaker and got this 400W 24 volt PSU. $49: http://bit.ly/QhazrA

  • Round up some wire heavy enough for the power. I used 12 gauge silicon insulated wire often used for RC cars. You will also need some thinner wire for wiring up the thermistor - I used 26 gauge. IMPORTANT: using too thin of wire for the heated bed or the new power supply can result in a FIRE. 12 gauge wire $12 from http://amzn.to/NyvBVu

  • Obtain an aluminum plate. I chose quarter inch, but I am sure thinner would be adequate. I chose mill finish as it is flatter then the non-milled stock. Material for two plates $24.95 from http://bit.ly/PMcKGI
    • Instructions:

  • Download the PDF or Illustrator file.

  • Generate G-Code for your machine. I used a 1/8" end mill. If you use anything larger the slots won't turn out. Since I didn't use any coolant I chose a federate for 18IPM and a depth of 0.01". Milled flawlessly with these settings on my machine.

  • Mill out the aluminum plate.

  • The new PSU connects exactly where the old PSU was connected.

  • Solder the power leads to the PCB.

  • Tape the PCB to the milled aluminum plate using Kapton tape.

  • Tape the thermistor to the aluminum plate very securely. WARNING: if the thermistor comes lose it could cause runaway over heating potentially causing a FIRE.

  • Drill a hole big enough for your wires at on the wood Z bed holder and in a safe location on the bottom of your Ultimaker.

  • Obtain a 4.7kohm resistor and follow the wiring instructions at: http://bit.ly/OySmo4

  • Feed the wires though the holes and mount your milled plate using the stock screws and springs.

  • Connect the PCB power leads to the 'HEATED3' terminals on the board.

  • The Thermistor connects to the first and third pins of the 'TEMP3' terminals. I soldered them on mine.

  • Adjust your z-limit switch for your new height.

  • Create custom firmware using Daid's excellent web interface at: http://bit.ly/O9EXbT . Only change settings if you know what you are doing. The only option you need to change is "Heated bed temperature sensor". If you bought the Thermistor from Ultamachine (link above) then choose "EPCOS 100K".

  • Click the "Build Marlin!" button, and when it appears click "Download: Windows Install zip" (even if you are on a Mac!).

  • Upload the new firmware. If you use Cura, choose "Install custom firmware" from the "Expert" menu option.

  • Cover your milled aluminum plate with Kapton tape and you now may ditch your blue tape!

  • When you first turn on the bed (I recommend manually testing with Printrun first) look under the milled aluminum plate and you should see a beautiful little red LED light glowing!

  • Start printing! You may need to adjust your "Bed temperature settings in your favorite slicer.

    • I think that is everything, let me know if I missed anything!

comments.text: Hi strainstress, in theory I could have used the same round plug, but the plug I received with the Ultimaker had reliability issues, so I soldered the new power supply to the board. For electronics you can't really have too much current, problems occur when you don't have enough current. It is the volts you have to be worried about having too many volts. Components will draw as much current as they need provided the current is available and all the wiring etc. is up to the task.

I cut a small PCB on my CNC machine for a relay that could switch enough current to control the heater. The heater connections on the ultimaker power the relay and the relay connects my second power supply to the heater.
I looked at the schematics for the 1.5.6 version of the board and you could probably just use the low-side transistor built into the control board like the Ultimaker wiki suggests, but I could not find a good place to connect the ground of my second power supply to the control board. I decided I would rather make the relay board than try to solder a large wire to the ground plane of the control board especially as I have the 1.5.7 version of the board and cannot find the schematics for it.
comments.author: we_love_robots

comments.text: I opted to connect it directly to the RAMPS board. Of course both options can work.

This is a basic spool holder I designed in Sketchup, after seeing some of the other spool holders here. My version is very simplistic, being just a triangle style frame held together by 1/4" wooden dowels.
You'll need a wire or rope spool from a hardware store, or another type of spool to utilize this holder. I am designing a printable spool that will be compatible with this holder, which I will add to this thing when I have it finished.
The horizontal holes do have a bit of an 'unsupported overhang' at the top, however mine printed without any issues (as you can see in the image). Your mileage may vary ;-).

Print 2 of each piece (top, footA, and footB). Use 1/4" wooden dowels to connect the pieces together. You'll need 6 equal sections for the sides, 2 equal sections for the front and back, and one slightly longer piece for the top. For my setup I used the following lengths: Sides (x6) : 240mm
Front/Back (x2): 230mm
Top (x1) : 255mm

description.text: I liked the original but couldn't print them because they were the max of my build space and overhangs because I didn't use support.  So I created these trays they are 80x80mm and have beveled edges so you don't need to use support.

Print and stack then gently shake.
Now that I think about it you can probably skip printing the Quarter tray because there's really no point for that one.
I designed these on tinkercad.
The more I look at them the more I think I might make them in circular cups that fit together.
I guess that's why I marked these as "This thing is a Work in Progress".

description.text:
Jonny Peppa, the young, good lookin' lad, we all wish we had around… and now, we can. This high rez 3d model of Jonny is uploaded in the following 4 versions: Ankles up solid
Waists up solid
Waist up hollow
Shoulders up solid They are in full scale but print great when scaled down as well.

Best printed with fine layer resolution and support. We printed it with 100 micron layers, on a raft, with dense support structure. Ensure there is plenty of support for the "bagginess in the behind". Enjoy your Jonny Peppa model and use him safely. Be sure to post your remixes!

Jonny Peppa, the young, good lookin' lad, we all wish we had aroundâ¦ and now, we can. This high rez 3d model of Jonny is uploaded in the following 4 versions: Ankles up solid

Shoulders up solid They are in full scale but print great when scaled down as well.

Best printed with fine layer resolution and support. We printed it with 100 micron layers, on a raft, with dense support structure. Ensure there is plenty of support for the "bagginess in the behind". Enjoy your Jonny Peppa model and use him safely. Be sure to post your remixes!

remixed_from.author: TeamTeamUSA
remixed_from.title: Bag Clip - Parametric with Keeper Holes

description.text: Some different sized bag clips. I wanted the sturdiness of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5627 and the one piece hinge of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2868 so I redesigned with the best aspects of both. I also removed the sharp edges so it is comfortable to apply pressure to it. UPDATE: Use v2 files

I've provided four sizes, 60mm, 80mm, 100mm and 120mm. The pictures show all but the 100mm. I printed in ABS with 3 walls and 10% infill and they seem the perfect balance between strength and flex.
Thanks to the others for inspiration. Please improve on my design and post a derivative!
UPDATE: 18th Sep 2012, I've added new versions (v2) that have an improved larger clip. I recommend using those instead of the originals.

description.text: Part of a series of popular buildings in Toronto's Beaches neighbourhood. I designed this in sketchup from photos of the Leuty Lifeguard Station in the Beaches. http://modmissy.com/2011/09/08/leuty-lifeguard-station/

I printed this without any supports a few times and ran into no real difficulty. The overhang warped upward a bit when approaching the bottom of the roof with PLA. title: SeeMeCNC H1.1 Steve's Extruder 50mm Fan Mount

description.text:
A 50mm fan mount for Steve's Extruder.
I was experiencing constant filament jams without a fan blowing on the extruder.
Designed for a 50mm fan, because that's what I had on hand.
Mounts using the bearing adjustment screws on the underside of the extruder (I'm not sure what these are called).

New Fan mount made for Prusa I3XL from DIYTechShop. This is not the extruder fan mount but the fan for the ramps board.
It fits a standard 60mm Fan.

I designed this to hold the ImmersionRC 600mW transmitter to the side of the Phantom 2 so to maintain easy access to the battery compartment.  
The transmitter case is removable for servicing (and is locked in with a screw) and additional cases could be made for other things.  
The transmitter is held in place by slots in the case and is secured using the antenna connector (my antenna has an adapter)

Printed on a Makerbot Replicator using PLA Printed the two leg adapters at 2 Shells, 25% Infill and at 0.10 mm layer height.
Printed the case standing up with the opening at the top and at 1 Shell, 100% Infill and at 0.10 mm layer height You will need to remove the plastic wrapper from the transmitter for it to slide into the housing

comments.text: Do you need longer screws with this for the legs? If so, were you able to find them easily?

comments.text: You will need longer screws for the legs, the screws I used had 15-16mm of thread length and they were a perfect fit, they were some hex head screws I had already but the length should be fairly common

This is dissection of a sphere into two identical pieces, which includes a hollow cavity when assembled. This is derived from the same basic OpenSCAD script as my previous Hemi-demi-sphere submission.

Build two copies of Hollowdemisphere.stl. Watch your first model carefully; it starts with a brief 45-degree overhang from a thin edge. If your printer doesn't use support material then the first 10 layers may need a little tuning. On Hollowdemisphere.stl the upper half of the model also exhibits an overhang. If this gives you too much trouble, try building the cylinderdemisphere.stl version instead; it eliminates the interior overhang by using a smaller cylindrical cavity at the expense of using more material.

title: Logitank, made for Logitraxx Vehicle Chassis Kit

description.text:
This is a body top made for the Logitraxx chassis. Logitraxx is an FPGA based robot kit built on the Tamiya vehicle chassis platform using a custom length board.
The bot was designed by SL Interphase, LLC
www.sl-interphase.com
We recently launched this on Kickstarter.
http://kck.st/W9gPef
The tank model files are still a work in progress so they may change as we refine the design.
Its main purpose was to be a learning platform for developing robotics using the Spartan 6 FPGA. The robot demonstrates the basics of hardware accelerated parallel executed functions. Its navigation firmware and obstacle avoidance is pure hardware. The robot does not have a CPU and does not run any software (though you could integrate a processor based board like Arduino to its GPIO if you wanted).
As for the mechanical parts, they are still a bit rough and require some filing for fitting. the holes on the front plate are for the IR sensors and headlights. There is no back plate since the motor gearbox on the back of the Logitraxx essentially serves as the back plate.
You see a quick clip of it with grey printed turret moving around here...
http://youtu.be/pnlI4pMppEk
Turn learn more about how an FPGA is different than a CPU, check out our Kickstarter video here...
http://youtu.be/jY_WHwBfKeY

The body fits the CSRC-55 servo rather snugly. We made it tight so that you could file it and fit it without glue. Makes it easy to disassemble later.
It bolts together using #4x1/2 for either wood or sheet metal available at most hardware stores.
The gaps on the front portion are for the Logitraxx IR sensors and headlights. If you don't need them on your own creation you can just fill them in.

comments.text: Can you make the code available?
comments.author: cotten

comments.text: In the video you say "Arduno Uno Mini" but I think you mean "Arduino Pro Mini".
comments.author: Artaex

comments.text: Yes, thats true.  The Pro Mini is what is shown.  Though its only an example.  The thing about FPGAs is that they are CPU agnostic.  They can be connected to anything really.  You can use the FPGA as the brain, or wire up the FPGA to another embedded board with its own CPU like Arduino and use it as an "assistant" brain.  Even a medium grade FPGA can put an Intel iCore processor to shame.  The Arduino's ATMega is not very powerful, but add in the FPGA and Arduino + FPGA = Intel iCore stomper.
comments.author: Artaex

comments.text: FPGAs have their uses. Prototyping is one of them. They are highly configurable. However they do not hold a candle to high end CPUs. Yes they stomp any ATMEL chip out there no question. Intel chips however not so much. They really don't compete in the same markets. A FPGA can be programmed to simulate a regular CPU but is far less efficient. The latest FPGAs are of course now being made through the Intel foundry. A new Intel server CPU series was also recently announced that includes a FPGA in package. The key with FPGAs is knowing how to program in VHDL or other hardware programming language.
comments.author: SLI

comments.text: CPUs are predefined silicon designed not for a specific, but "generic" operation.  An FPGA is an undefined fabric of logic cells and connections that can be constructed into almost anything.  Where they work best is application specific duties where the logic is narrowly defined around the task.  In this form, no generic silicon can compete with it, not even Intel's fastest CPUs.  Where many FPGA developers go wrong is they attempt to duplicate the "generic" CPU function as an FSM soft core, passing on the inherent inefficiency of most software in general "wait-in-line" philosophy of single instruction execution.
comments.author: caster66

comments.text: There are pieces missing.
comments.author: Runningfox

comments.text: They are all there.  There is only a front, body, turret, gun and sides.  The Tamiya twin motor serves as the back and of course the circuit board is the bottom.  Wheels are other parts are from the Tamiya Vehicle Chassis Kit.
comments.author: Runningfox

comments.text: Can you attach the URL To the wheels?
comments.author: SLI

comments.text:
You can find the wheels in a lot of different vendors by searching under "Tamiya Vehicle Chassis Kit". Here's as good a link as any...
http://www.amazon.com/Tamiya-Tracked-Vehicle-Chassis-Kit/dp/B002DR3H5S/ref=sr_1_1?ie=UTF8&qid=1399348773&sr=8-1&keywords=tamiya+vehicle+chassis+kithttp://www.amazon.com/Tamiya-T...
You will have to switch out the single driver motor for the Tamiya twin motor gearbox of course and cut out your own base board. The wooden board that comes with the kit is too short for the tank components. They are designed to fit our own board. Of course you could resize the tank parts if you wanted as well.
comments.author: Runningfox

This is an improved simple sample holder for peices of semiconductor wafers for optical experiments. This component is part of the Open-source optics project, whose goal is to radically reduce the cost of scientific optical hardware: by the Michigan Tech's Open Sustainability Technology Research Group. For similar see the Open-Source Lab How to Build Your Own Hardware and Reduce Research Costs

This open-source sample holder is designed to hold a semiconductor wafer part on a smooth 8mm diameter rod. This is an improvement on the last version - as now you can change samples easily using tweezers and one hand only. It uses less plastic than v2 and has a cutout for samples that are short. Print on your favorite open source 3-D printer and enjoy. You can hold it to the smooth rod using m3s and the thumbscrew. Use the thumb screw from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:30500 If you need the base go to http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:28133 Full information here Thanks to Chenlong for designs on 3D Studio Max. This component is part of the Open-source Optics Library: Zhang C, Anzalone NC, Faria RP, Pearce JM (2013) Open-Source 3D-Printable Optics Equipment. PLoS ONE 8(3): e59840. This is part of a larger project to reduce the cost of scientific equipment using open-source hardware. Read more here

Wade's original geared extruder block is too big to print on a makerbot.
I remade the extruder block in OpenSCAD so that I could then carefully downscale parts of the extruder block to make it manageable.  (I was inspired by the guy who used OpenSCAD to "patch" the original STL to take a BfB hot end, but for what I wanted to do it seemed better to recreate the whole thing).

As it is, the scad file gives you the smaller version, but you can comment out a few lines to get the original size, or feel free to slice and dice your own variations.
The STL is positioned to avoid the back 3mm of the makerbot build platform and build up and out over the front by a couple of mm. This is because my Y idler pulley prevents access to the back 3mm of my build platform.
When printed, there are a couple of thin disks that you need to drill through where the main m8 bolt goes through, they are there to make some of the gap closings printable.

comments.text: So, warning.. (I'm not sure if this is a warning about just this modified version or of the original Wade's extruder version as well, but looking at both in Pleasant3D I think it's more a warning about this version):  The PTFE hole is off-center, and the way the holes are laid out, the PTFE and heater are far closer to the front of the x-carriage than the back.
comments.author: jkeegan

comments.text: It was also commented on here:
comments.author: jkeegan

comments.text: Ah - I'd found Tony's pic, but couldn't find any discussion where he'd mentioned it.
comments.author: Lenbok

comments.text: The original version has the same filament drive/mount spacing. If you use openscad, you can compare by uncommenting the line to import the original M8_Extruder_Block_3.stl and overlay them to verify (it helps to turn off perspective view).
comments.author: jkeegan

comments.text: Nice, although the title is a bit misleadng.  The original Alibre design is fully parametric as well; that's one of the main reasons why I use Alibre.  It would be more accurate to call this an "OpenSCAD" version.
comments.author: Wade

comments.text: Updated the title. Alibre is not an option for many people due to price and unavailability on their platform of choice, plus OpenSCAD is what all the cool kids are using these days :-).  Perhaps you can also attach your Alibre files to the thingiverse page for those that are able to use Alibre?
comments.author: Wade

This caulk plug prevents the contents of a caulk tube from drying out between uses.

comments.text: Just made one and it's awesome! I can't seem to figure out what the side 'C' shaped structure is for though. Any help?
comments.author: Pepsima

comments.text: Thanks for getting back to me! I realize why the interior pin is there, and also know it is NOT meant to puncture the tube, but merely to plug it to help prevent drying and oozing. I think the pin needs to be thicker so it will be stronger and not as prone to breakage if your device is not put on and removed carefully. This problem would be easily solved with a better building material than I am using(ABS) as well. Keep up the great work!
comments.author: robrook

comments.text: I made this great idea, see downloaded photo. Unfortunately, as it stands, it is not durable enough for the task at hand. If it is thickened up that may help considerably. It may not LOOK quite as appealing, but it will likely function better. Finally, I am not quite sure what the cylindrical tube with the split side is to be used for. To store it somewhere while not in use? I really like the idea and the design though GREAT  JOB!!!
comments.author: robrook

WIRED letter blocks as seen on the cover of the October 2012 issue Created by Todd Blatt

Some clean up will be needed for stray strands of plastic inside the wormy letters.  Tweezers or needle nosed pliers will do the trick.  For ABS printing of the WRD blocks, try using the .stl files with the pads.  These letters should just slip together, and were printed with 1 extra shell and 0% infill for the wormy letters, and 1 shell and 10% infill for the solid letters.
-Todd

title: Gear shift knob for Volvo V40

description.text:
The rubber-foamy top of he shift knob on my car became loose and i needed a temporary replacement.
Its for the older V40, i think from 1998.
Use at your own risk...

Support is needed for the inner profile. You may try to turn it upsidedown, but i didnt get a nice finish on the top that way.
1st try was printed using PLA. Its a tight fit on the lever which needs a lot of force to remove it. 2nd try was printed using wood filament which was still tight but more easy to remove. As it looks so much better than PLA i think i will glue it on.

author: tlo

description.text: I made this fixture to hold a Beaglebone Black cape circuit board while machining. I needed to cut a notch in the board to clear the RJ45 connector on the main board. I used it again, with the transverse slot to shorten a circuit board. You can add other holes and slots to suit your purposes.  It held the board without and problems and I didn't have to worry about hitting the end mills on anything hard (like the mill vise).
Printed in PLA 185/60 at 0.20mm layer size.

This is the original Android robot platform from 2010, now fully open sourced. Contact me for electronics schematics. Will work with a Picaxe, Arduino, Propeller or MSP430 microcontroller. The motors are a Tamiya 70168 twin gearbox kit. You can make a battery out of two laptop battery cells, and it'll fit right past the motor. Four AA cells will also fit. Videos here: https://www.youtube.com/user/Spiritplumber Android app here: https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=re.anywhere.client Video of this particular Antbot here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hqrzer7aG-c&feature=youtu.be (Credit to Ahmet Oguz)

comments.text: how do the tracks hold up?  Made in ABS?  or something more exotic?
comments.author: bosnyak

comments.text: The tracks are ABS, everything else can be either ABS or PLA. This is not a very fast robot, so they will hold up. You can also use Tamiya tracks, just use the large roller on the driving wheels, and the small roller on the lower hole in the back for the idlers.

message = DL 2014

This Meso Material (mm scale material) is based on a sphere composed of orthogonal circles.  It forms a cartesian grid in which none of the balls touches another when spaced apart.  Physically, of course, they will touch and act springy which will give the material interesting properties most likely.  
If you wish to publish, copyright, or patent this thing then please contact me.

Please use the balls4.scad file for Customizer and OpenSCAD runs, and the corresponding output file of balls4_3-3-3.stl which is the 3x3x3 version of balls4.scad.  All other files remain included for reference only.  
I have had these things printed at Shapeways, and they found that the earlier files could only be printed about half of the time with success due to design rule violation (thickness 0.71mm instead of 0.8mm, slightly too thin).  The balls4.scad file uses minimum feature size of sort(2) mm (about 1.4 mm) so much larger and round too.  Also please note that the ball size is larger on balls4.scad outputs so the cost is higher.  
The shape to be printed at shape ways is available in my shape ways account (user ID same as thingiverse:  CreatorLes), or you can open your own account at any printer that can do the job and use your own stl file.  
For printing technology please note that these balls are not attached to each other and there is a small clearance between them, so they cannot be easily printed on MakerBot printers.  You might want to make a version that is printable on MakerBot printers, or perhaps I will upon request.

comments.text: Update:  So far I have sold three of these to other people so I hope that somebody somewhere is going to make use of this thing.  That's cool.  I make $1.45 on each sample by the way, which I will try not to spend all in one place :).
comments.author: deltaModulator

comments.text: I just ordered three 3x3x3 samples of this meso-material from shapeways in white flexible plastic.  Hopefully it is manufacturable by them, or else I'll choose another material.  Funny thing is, all three with shipping is only $16.00 so $5.33 each including shipping.  A larger order would knock that down even further.  I should be able to send a few samples out into the universe and see if anything comes of it.  Do you want one of these?  I'll sell them at cost plus shipping, or just order directly from shape ways (CreatorLes there also).
comments.author: deltaModulator

description.text: This is one of the reasons that I love my makerbot. I needed a way to keep my front gate from swinging shut.  This clip has just enough flex to allow the gate to pop under the lip on the front.
Print out the clip, and screw to the post with a couple of self tapping screws. Cease to try to hold the gate open with one foot while dragging the pram through.

comments.text: This is very excellent in its simplicity.  When owning a 3D printer comes with the side benefit of having a library of little household widgets, that sub-1000$ price tag starts to look more and more reasonable.
comments.author: MaskedRetriever

description.text:
Wanted to find a way to mount my 30A flat pack ebay power supply. This bracket is designed to mount the power supply on the underside of the Reprap Prusa printer. 
The bracket is made parametric to allow easy adaptation if you do not have right length screw.
NOTE: The STL file provided is 32mm wide from the rod to the power supply. May not fit for some printers.

Additional material:
  • m3x25mm and m4x20mm screws
  • m3x(>16)mm screw and m3 nut (optional, for bar clamp)
  • Measure the distance between the back of the printer to the center rod and the width of the power supply.
  • Take the difference of the measurements and divide the result by 2.
  • Enter the final measurement to bracket_width in OpenSCAD
  • Compile/Render -> print and mount
    • The bracket may be a tight fit when mounting.

comments.text:
Recently I've bought an Lian-Li Power Supply
Extension Bracket. It allows extra long power supplies, like the heavy duty
1000W + models, to fit in smaller case or simply take less room in a
larger case. The bracket replaces the normal, flat Lian-Li power supply
bracket and holds the unit securely to the case back.
Thanks,@Nadia from
comments.author: nadia123450

author: MobileMaker

description.text: The LYMAN FILAMENT SPOOL WINDER is an accessory to the LYMAN FILAMENT EXTRUDER, wherein the winder winds onto a spool the filament as it is extruding from the extruder.

The PDF file LYMAN FILAMENT SPOOL WINDER MANUAL is a complete manual for fabrication and operation instructions, including BOM, tools, photo's and drawings. This device works great, but final testing will not be done till I receive my extruder back from Desktop Factory Competition. View Video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=k3lul6rw3H4&feature=youtu.be Comments and suggestions are welcomed.

comments.text:
Hi Folks,
Sorry, I am not replying to anymore comments on the filament winder. I am so busy with LYMAN / MULIER FILAMENT EXTRUDER V5 that I just don't have the time and I am old and tired. If you are capable of building one you may be capable of designing your own.
Bye.
comments.author: hlyman

comments.text:
Does it rotate at constant rate or changes according to how much material was extruded (sensor of some sort) ?
Thanks !
comments.author: tonycstech

comments.text: The gear motor rotates at a constant speed.  The spool rotates only as fast as the filament allows.  The latex tube on the motor shaft slips on the spool edge as it turns it.  See my Thing "LYMAN / MULIER FILAMENT EXTRUDER V5"  which shows the latest winder with a level wind mechanism.
comments.author: tonycstech

comments.text:
"only as fast as the filament allows" tells me little to no information.
Filament does not restrict anything, it comes out at 160 (PLA) or 190 (ABS) at the tip of the nozzle so there is hardly any resistance for it being too soft.
Do you have a sensor in place that detects the pulling force or you measure the sag of the filament as everybody else does ?
comments.author: hlyman

comments.text: The pull roller maintains a constant speed so the filament winds tightly on the spool.  The spool speed varies and slows down as the diameter of the filament on the spool increases.  There is no sensor.  I don't sell any of my things.
comments.author: tonycstech

comments.text:
Spool diameter increase slows down the spool rotation is very clear, but i worry about the filament diameter, not the filament wrapped around the spool.
Is it possible that this setup pulls on the filament hard enough to make it thinner or not enough that it would make it thicker ?
Do you have a DIY on this winder that people can follow to build one of their own ?
comments.author: hlyman

comments.text: I suggest you download the manual and read it.
comments.author: tonycstech

comments.text:
Where ? No link anywhere except for youtube video and even there there is no info on where to go from there.
Thanks !
comments.author: hlyman

comments.text: its the first file in the downloads (PDF, 3mb file).
comments.author: tonycstech

comments.text: What is required for the power supply?  I am looking at making the filament extruder also and looking at getting a 12v 5amp PSU.
comments.author: zachjowi

comments.text: that will work.  I think my motors used less than 1 amp.
comments.author: zachjowi

comments.text: I saw one of these in action today. It occurred to me that the speed that the motor turning the spool pulled the filament onto the spool would increase as the diameter of the spooled filament increased. This could be remedied simply by turning the spool with a wheel against the inside of the spool rather than the rim. As the filament accumulated on the spool, the wheel would run against the already spooled filament, changing the effective gear ratio as the diameter of the spooled filament increased. This would all mean that the speed that the spool turned would be constant in terms of millimeters per minute of plastic being wrapped around the spool rather than being constant in terms of degrees per minute of rotation.
comments.author: whosawhatsis

comments.text: It would be cool to use this to spool the filament directly from the extruder without letting it pile on the dusty floor.  It seems that it would be difficult to set the speed of the spooler to match the rate of extrusion accurately enough to not pull too much or fall too far behind over many hours.
comments.author: ianjohnson

comments.text: That is exatly what I plan to do when my extruder is returned to me from Inventables. Two optical switches about 6" off the floor between the extruder and the spool winder.  Thanks for bringing this up.
comments.author: ianjohnson

comments.text: Then it will be another "filawinder", exactly what am trying to stay away from :)
comments.author: hlyman

comments.text:
Excellent work. Some questions: Is your power supply 12V or 24V?
What is the rpm of the 12V DC motor?
Also many of your ebay seller's item does not exist. So validating your document pricewise is a bit hard.
comments.author: laszlo

comments.text:
Â The charger power supply is a simple 24V DC 600mA adapter that cost me about $5.00.Â  I had it on hand.
